column1: Ustroń [ˈustrɔɲ] (listen) (German: Ustron) is a health resort town in Cieszyn Silesia
column2: southern Poland. It is situated in the Silesian Voivodeship (since 1999)
column3: having previously been in Bielsko-Biała Voivodeship (1975–1998). It lies in the Silesian Beskids mountain range.

column1: It is the home of the Jan Jarocki Museum
column2: which was founded in April 1986 as Museum of Metallurgy. It is housed in an old building of the former Klemens Steel Works
column3: which was in use between 1772 and 1897. The museum collects technical tools
column4: as well as historical and ethnographic artifacts.

column1: The Równica and Czantoria mountains are nearby and hikable from the town center.

The settlement was first mentioned in a Latin document of Diocese of Wrocław called Liber fundationis episcopatus Vratislaviensis from around 1305 as item in Ustrona. It meant that the village was in the process of location (the size of land to pay a tithe from was not yet precise). The creation of the village was a part of a larger settlement campaign taking place in the late 13th century on the territory of what would later be known as Upper Silesia.

column2: the village belonged initially to the Duchy of Teschen

column3: the Klemens Steel Works was opened and the village was gradually industrialised. When the steel work was closed in 1897 the market town switched to be more orientated towards a health and spa resort.
